member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.BlockKeyedCollection`1.TakeOffline
member.summary: Temporarily suspends automatic regeneration and integrity checks on .

remarks.para: This method is useful for take the collection in an "offline" state and speed up the editing/reorganization. To resume the standard behaviour call .
Beware when the collection is "offline", it can lead to an inconsistent state and crash with methods like , , etc.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.EntityList.MaxCandidates
member.summary: Accurate transparency. This parameter affects transparency pre-processing and redrawing speed. Valid values are between 1 and the total number of semi-transparent triangles. The lower is this value the lower will be the time need for pre-processing, penalizing redrawing speed. Higher values normally improve the FPS rate.

member.summary: Accurate transparency. If true, skips back facing semi-tranparent triangles drawing, increasing the FPS rate.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FastMesh.ColorArray
member.summary: Gets or sets the color array.

remarks.para: The size of the array determines how the colors are applied to the entity:

item.description: 1 byte per vertex is applied as a modulation factor (0-255) to the of the entity. This requires the use of shaders so the graphics acceleration must be turned on, must be true (WinForms control only) and the must be
3 bytes per vertex are applied as RGB colors
4 bytes per vertex are applied as RGBA colors (in order for the alpha transparency to work, the entity must also have a with alpha < 255 and must be set to false).

member.summary: Fast point cloud entity. Suitable for huge number of points.

member.summary: Gets or sets point cloud drawing style.

member.summary: Gets or sets point array.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FastPointCloud.ColorArray
member.summary: Gets or sets the color array.
member.remarks: The size of the array determines how the colors are applied to the entity: 1 byte per vertex is applied as a modulation factor (0-255) to the of the entity. This requires the use of shaders so the graphics acceleration must be turned on, must be true (Winforms Eyeshot control only) and the must be 3 bytes per vertex are applied as RGB colors 4 bytes per vertex are applied as RGBA colors (in order for the alpha transparency to work, the entity must also have a with alpha < 255 and must be set to false).

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FastPointCloud.ZoomFitSpeed
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of points skipped during zoom fit and bounding box computation.

remarks.para: This value indicates how often a point is chosen. In practice, we take one, discard 'n' and then take another, and so on.
Set to 0 for accurate ZoomFit and bounding box, increase for better performance.

summary.para: BRep solid entity definition. A manifold solid B-rep is a finite, arcwise connected volume bounded by one or more surfaces, each of which is a connected, oriented, finite, closed 2-manifold. There is no restriction on the genus of the volume, nor on the number of voids within the volume.

The Boundary Representation (B-rep) of a manifold solid utilizes a graph of edges and vertices embedded in a connected, oriented, finite, closed two manifold surface. The embedded graph divides the surface into arcwise connected areas known as faces. The edges and vertices, therefore, form the boundaries of the face and the domain of a face does not include its boundaries. The embedded graph may be disconnected and may be a pseudo graph. The graph is labeled; that is, each entity in the graph has a unique identity. The geometric surface definition used to specify the geometry of a face shall be 2-manifold embeddable in the plane within the domain of the face. In other words, it shall be connected, oriented, finite, non-self-intersecting, and of surface genus 0.

Faces do not intersect except along their boundaries. Each edge along the boundary of a face is shared by at most one other face in the assemblage. The assemblage of edges in the B-rep do not intersect except at their boundaries (i.e., vertices). The geometry curve definition used to specify the geometry of an edge shall be arcwise connected and shall not self intersect or overlap within the domain of the edge. The geometry of an edge shall be consistent with the geometry of the faces of which it forms a partial bound. The geometry used to define a vertex shall be consistent with the geometry of the faces and edges of which it forms a partial bound.
A B-rep is represented by one or more closed shells which shall be disjoint. One shell, the outer, shall completely enclose all the other shells and no other shell may enclose a shell.

member.summary: Creates a Brep from skinning.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.knotVectorType.PiecewiseBezier
member.summary: Another common knot vector format is for piecewise Bézier curves. These are usually used when a bunch of simple primitives, such as arcs, lines or simple curve segments are strung together into a single large curve. Again, if k is the order, then the curve passes through each k’th point on the curve, and passes near all of the others. In other words, the curve is broken into segments of k points each. Moving any control point within a particular segment affects only that segment, and moving a point where two segments join affects both. If the joint and the control points on either side of it are in a straight line, then the two segments form a smooth continuous curve.3 Otherwise a sharp “kink” or discontinuity occurs. Example: {0,0,0, 1,1, 2,2, 3,3,3}

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Curve.Fillet(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Arc@)
member.summary: Fillets two coplanar curves with an arc of given radius.
member.param: When true the first curve is trimmed
When true the second curve is trimmed
member.returns: True if the operation is successful, false if the curves don't lie on the same plane or don't touch.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Curve.Fillet(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Arc@)
member.summary: Fillets two coplanar curves with an arc of given radius.
member.param: Unit vector, normal to the plane on which both curves lie.
When true the first curve is trimmed
When true the second curve is trimmed
member.returns: True if the operation is successful, false if the curves don't lie on the same plane or don't touch.
member.remarks: Looking at the curves from the top of planeNormal placed at the intersection, the fillet will be on the left side of a curve if its flip parameter is false, and on the right side if its flip is true. Use planeNormal only if you know exactly how the curves are oriented and where you want the fillet to be placed. Otherwise, set it to null or call the Fillet() method without planeNormal and we will compute it internally.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.OrdinateDim
member.summary:
Ordinate dimension entity.
The ordinate dimension consists of an X or Y value with a leader line.
It measures the perpendicular distance from an origin point (called the datum) to a defining point (such as a hole in a part).
X-datum ordinate dimensions measure the distance of the defining point from the datum along the X axis.
Y-datum ordinate dimensions measure the distance of the defining point from the datum along the Y axis.
If the dimension is vertical it measures the X value. Otherwise, it measures the Y value.
member.remarks: Text font can be changed using the property and calling the Environment.Entities.Regen() method.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.OrdinateDim.#ctor(devDept.Geometry.Plane,devDept.Geometry.Point3D,devDept.Geometry.Point3D,System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: Standard constructor.
member.param: The dimension plane. Its origin is used to measure the distance from the defining point.
The type of the ordinate dimension (horizontal or vertical). If true, the x-coordinate is measured, otherwise the y-coordinate is measured.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Mesh

summary.para: A triangle mesh is a type of polygon mesh in computer graphics. It comprises a set of triangles (typically in three dimensions) that are connected by their common edges or corners.
Depending on the types of vertices and triangles, it can assume different configurations, see table below.

item.description: Plain1
MulticolorPlain
Smooth1
MulticolorSmooth
ColorPlain
ColorSmooth
RichPlain
RichSmooth

summary.para: 1 Allows transparency to be used

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Mesh.ApplyMaterial(System.String,devDept.Eyeshot.textureMappingType,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Maps the specified material to this mesh. Before using this method you need to define a material and add it to the collection.

remarks.para: The mesh nature is set to RichPlain or RichSmooth from this command.
You may need to call viewport.Entities.Regen() to see the effect of this command.

member.summary: Create a base flange by offsetting and Extruding the curve after fillet the corners.
member.param: The bend radius replacing the corners
When true, it thickens the linear path in the opposite direction

member.returns: True if the curve is oriented clockwise, false otherwise.
member.remarks: If the curve is not planar, the points are projected on the plane.

member.summary: When true, enables anisotropic filtering for mipmapping.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Picture.MinifyingFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture minifying function. The texture minifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area greater than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Picture.MagnifyingFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture magnifying function. The texture magnifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area smaller than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.

member.summary: HatchPattern definition. The pattern is defined by a collection of HatchPatternLine. The process of hatching consists of expanding each line to its infinite family of parallel lines. member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Layer
member.summary: Layer definition. Layers are a way to group objects so that the groups can have common formatting. For example, you may want your objects to show up in one color and your dimensions to show in another. Create a separate layer for each, then you can change all the dimensions or all the objects at the same time. You may show or hide layers, change the color, lineweight, or linetype. Layers are utilized often to make drawings easier to read.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.LineType
member.summary: LineType class. The pattern defines pen-up lengths (spaces), pen-down lengths (dashes), and dots. A pattern specifies the length of segments that make up the linetype. A positive decimal number specifies a pen-down (dash) segment of that length. A negative decimal number specifies a pen-up (space) segment of that length. Zero specifies a dot. For example, the DASHDOT linetype is defined by a repeating pattern starting with a dash 0.5 drawing units long, a space 0.25 drawing units long, a dot, and another space 0.25 drawing units long.
member.remarks: When the line type used by entities already added to the is changed, their must be set to and the must be called.
Use an empty pattern for a continuous line.

member.summary: Sets a BlockReference as current.

If true, updates the scene bounding box. Set it to false for better performances in off-screen methods that call this to just use the

remarks.para: If it is null, the current BlockReference is unset.
The BlockReference must be a first-level child of the one that is currently set (i.e. it must be in the entities of the ).
When a BlockReference is set as current, only the referenced block entities are active on the scene, others are still visible but in a "frozen" state.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.UpdateBoundingBox
member.summary: Computes the scene bounding box, rebuilds simplified representation and updates some important variables. If the bounding box, grid or shadow are visible, it updates them too.

remarks.para: Shadow is updated only if it is visible and if the model has the bounding box height bigger than zero.
It's important to call this method when the visibility status of some entities changes.
Visual refinement deviation is updated as well but you need to set as for all entities and call to see objects with new tessellation.

member.summary: Occurs when the touch surface is double-clicked.
member.remarks: WPF doesn't expose the double touch as an explicit event, so this is a custom event based on the fact that the application can receive a TwoFingerTap Gesture via the StylusSystemGesture event, which typically maps to double-click on a mouse. member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.ForceHardwareAcceleration
member.summary: Forces accelerated hardware modes. By default, Eyeshot automatically disables hardware acceleration on some embedded GPUs to obtain the maximum level of graphical output consistency between all hardware. In these cases, enabling this property will forcibly activate hardware acceleration, though the resulting graphics output may be unpredictable.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.Entities

member.remarks: Never add a block definition to this collection. Add it to the blocks collection.

member.summary: Temporary Entity collection. This collection contains the entities displayed in the viewport on top of the others as temporary entities.
member.remarks: Only IFace and ICurve types are supported into this collection. Each entity added to this list needs to the regenerated first.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.RemoveJittering(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a block with the selected , computes the center of their bounding box, translates them all of the negative of that quantity and returns a BlockReference to that block.
member.param: The name of the block that will contain the selected entities.
member.returns: The blockReference referring to the created block.
member.remarks: When the entities are very far from the origin their appearance on screen may become very compromised, and the camera may shake badly when moving/rotating the view. To fix this issue you can select these entities and call this method.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.RemoveJittering(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.BlockReference)
member.summary: Gets the blockreference entities, computes the center of their bounding box, translates them all of the negative of that quantity and translates the blockreference back to the original position.
member.param: The blockreference name of the block that will contain the selected entities.
member.remarks: When the entities are very far from the origin their appearance on screen may become very compromised, and the camera may shake badly when moving/rotating the view. To fix this issue you can select these entities and call this method.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.SaveScene(System.String)
member.summary: Saves the current scene on disk, including entities, textures, blocks and layouts.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.SaveScene(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Saves the current scene on disk, including entities, textures, blocks and layouts.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.
The closing of the stream is delegated to you.

summary.para: Restores the current scene from disk, including entities, textures, blocks and labels.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.

summary.para: Restores the current scene from disk, including entities, textures, blocks and labels.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.
The closing of the stream is delegated to you.

member.remarks: Has no effect at runtime.
Applies to renderer only.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.AskForDirect3DLevel9_3
member.summary: If true, The Direct3D feature level 9_3 is requested during viewport initialization instead of the highest feature level available.
member.remarks: Used for compatibility problems with old cards.
Has no effect at runtime.
Direct3D feature level 9_3 has some limitations and does not support all the features of higher profiles
Applies only to renderer.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.AskForAntiAliasing
member.summary: If true, Full Screen Anti-Aliasing modes are requested during viewport initialization. The number of samples can be set with the property.
member.remarks: Has no effect at runtime for the OpenGL renderer.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.AntiAliasing
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if full screen anti-aliasing is enabled.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.AntiAliasingSamples
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of desired samples for Full Screen Anti-Aliasing. The Full Screen Anti-alasing can be set with the property.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.RendererVendor

member.remarks: OpenGL only.

member.summary: Gets OpenGL Shading Language version.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.OpenglExtensions
member.summary: Gets a space-separated list of supported extensions to OpenGL.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.RendererName
member.summary: Gets the name of the renderer. This name is typically specific to a particular configuration of a hardware platform. It does not change from release to release.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.RendererVersion
member.summary: Gets graphics API version.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.MaxPatternRepetitions
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of pattern repetitions allowed between two vertices of a curve.
member.remarks: Over this bias the line is drawn continuous without pattern.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.MaxHatchPatternLines
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of hatch pattern lines allowed for each .
member.remarks: Over this bias the Hatch is drawn with solid pattern.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.CompileWires

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.MakeLoop(System.Collections.Generic.IList{devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve},System.Int32,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Analyzes a number of entities and returns a closed loop of points starting from the entity at . You can provide an array of 100 entities an get a 3D loop of a square made up of 4 lines. Entities connection is checked using parameter, if the end points of two entities are farther of this value they will not be connected.
member.param: If true, reverses the loop orientation.

member.summary: Triangulates the specific region.
member.param: The loop list, the outer one is the first (needs to be oriented counterclockwise), the inners are the others (need to be oriented clockwise).

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase
member.summary: Base class for lead and ramp. Holds a set of points which can be rotated and translated to be tangent to a given stroke.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.CutDirection
member.summary: Machining cut direction mode, needed to orient leads and ramps correctly. The attribute is updated internally before computing lead positions.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.Points
member.summary: Points of the lead. The point list must start from .

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.InterPoints
member.summary: Points used to compute intersections; can be null.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.Tangent(devDept.Geometry.Point3D[],System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a vector tangent to the lead point. The lead point is the point in the stroke array specified by the index parameter. The vector is constructed taking either the point before or the point after the lead point, based on the nextTangent parameter.
member.param: An array of points that represents a polygonal chain
Index in the stroke array of the lead point; to avoid exceptions, the index has to be less than the stroke array length and greater than 0 if nextTangent is false
When true, the vector is constructed using the point next to the lead point; when false, the point before is used instead
member.returns: A vector tangent to the stroke polygonal chain, either tangent to the segment after the lead point or the segment before.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.OrientPoints(devDept.Geometry.Point3D[],devDept.Geometry.Point3D[],System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Orients (translates and rotates) the given array of points to be tangent to the given stroke in a specified point. The point in the stroke array specified by the index parameter is the lead point. This method is used to translate and to the lead point.
member.param: Array of points to be oriented; if the first point of the array is (as it should) it will be translated to be exactly on the lead point.
An array of points which represents a polygonal chain
Index of the lead point in the stroke array; to avoid exceptions, the index has to be less than the stroke array length and greater than 0 if nextTangent is false
When true, the points array is oriented to be tangent to the segment after the lead point; when false, it is oriented to be tangent to the segment before the lead point

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.BuildAsLollipop(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Approximate the lead as a lollipop, generating the intersection points using the specified radius and distance. A lollipop is a segment connected to a circle, which can be used to compute intersections more quickly. For example, a helix ramp can be approximated to a circle of the same radius. The lollipop circle is made up of 16 segments.
member.param: Distance from the contour to the lower point of the circle.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.Init(devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.cutDirectionType)
member.summary: Init cut direction; this method has to be called once before using .

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp
member.summary: Base class for ramp movements, vertical movements between Z levels, defining how the end mill should ramp into the stock. A ramp is a movement that the end mill has to perform while descending into the stock, before leading in and cutting the material. A ramp movement (if present) always comes before the cut, and never after.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.radialClearance
member.summary: Not yet supported.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.clearanceHeight
member.summary: The clearance height is the height reached by the tool with rapid movements. The ramp will be built ensuring that a distance in Z equal to the clearance height is kept between the start point of the ramp and the top of the remaining material.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Ramp standard constructor.
member.param: The height of ramp over the current stock level

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.Init(devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.cutDirectionType,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Update the ramp based on the current cut direction and layer height (height of the material which has to be milled). The ramp will be updated by calling this method multiple times during the ramp addition process, after the toolpath has been computed. Child classes should override this method to update the Points and (when needed) the InterPoints arrays based on the tolerance and the layer height.
member.param: The cut direction of the stroke where the ramp has to be placed; see
Tolerance to build the ramp; see
Height of the current level (part of the stock which has to be cut). The total height of the ramp should be equal to layerHeight + clearanceHeight.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.PlungeRamp
member.summary: Plunge ramp movement definition. A plunge ramp is a vertical straight movement which digs into the stock directly.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.PlungeRamp.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Standard constructor.
member.param: The height of ramp over the current stock level.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.HelixRamp
member.summary: Helix ramp movement definition. A helix ramp is a helical movement which digs into the stock gradually with circular motions.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.HelixRamp.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Standard constructor.
member.param: The height of ramp over the current stock level

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Lead
member.summary: Represents a lead (lead-in or lead-out), defining the movement of the tool as it approaches or leaves the stock. A lead-in is the motion of the tool before beginning a cutting move, while a lead-out is the motion of the tool as it ends the cut and leaves the material.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Lead.#ctor
member.summary: Standard constructor.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Lead.Init(devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.cutDirectionType,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Used internally to update the tolerance and the cut direction. The Init method should be overridden by child classes to update the Points and (when needed) the InterPoints arrays based on the tolerance and the lead type (lead-in or lead-out).
member.param: Tolerance to generate the lead, see
True if the lead is a lead-in and will be used to approach the path, false if the lead is a lead-out and will serve to exit the path.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.StraightLead
member.summary: Straight lead (perpendicular or tangent). Defines a lead with a single segment, which can be perpendicular or tangent to the cutting motion.

member.summary: Straight lead standard constructor.

member.summary: When true unused items of master collections, such as block definitions, layers, etc. are not written.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.WriteFileParams.SaveThumbnail
member.summary: When true and the Model constructor is used, a thumbnail of 256x256 is stored in the file.
member.remarks: To save the thumbnail the graphics rendering context must have already been initialized.
member.exception: Thrown when trying to set the property equal true without using the constructor that accepts the Environment as parameter.

members.member:
Gets or sets the background color for the thumbnail.
If empty, the thumbnail will be saved with a white background. .

member.summary: Constructor with the .
member.param: When true, only selected entities at root level are written.
When true, a thumbnail picture is stored.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.WriteMultiFileParams.UpdateThumbnails
member.summary: Indicates whether the thumbnail must be updated for all the written files or not. Default value is false and the thumbnail is stored only for the main file according to param.
member.remarks: When true and is true too, the thumbnail is updated for all files. This operation cannot be run in parallel and can increase a lot the working time for this work unit.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.WriteMultiFileParams.Parallel
member.summary: Indicates whether the writing of the files is performed in parallel or not (Default is True).
member.remarks: The updating of thumbnails is excluded from parallel process.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.ReadLAS.GetFastPointCloud(devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.ReadFastPointCloudBase.formatType)
member.summary: Gets the FastPointCloud read from the file.
member.param: The that must be used to create the resulting FastPointCloud.
member.returns: The FastPointCloud read from the file according to the .
member.remarks: If you need to get the FastPointCloud in a different format type than the one used in the constructor, please ensure to have set , and to true before reading the file.

members.member:
Gets the FastPointCloud read from the file as Block.
The that must be used to create the resulting FastPointCloud. The to use as insertion point for the creation of the related . The name of the block. If null/Nothing the name is assigned internally. The block containing the FastPointCloud read from the file.
Uses a block reference to avoid floating point precision problems. i.e. When files use the UTM 32 North projection with northing values > 5,000,000 and easting values > 435,000, the northing values are larger than the easting values and the limited precision of the floats leads to the points arranged in the lines. To get more accurated result, you can use double precision coordinates by setting to true before starting the reading process. If you need to get the FastPointCloud in a different format type than the one used in the constructor, please ensure to have set , and to true before reading the file.
.

summary.para: When true, entities at the same level of BlockReferences are encapsulated inside a new block.

Many CAD systems have difficulties to handle individual entities at the same level of BlockReferences. Using this flag, all individual entities at the same level of BlockReferences are replaced by a BlockReference with a name at random.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Model.StartAnimation

summary.para: Starts the animation timer. After calling this method the Animate method of all the entities is called periodically to allow the computation of the new entity position.
To animate group of entities the approach is the following:

item.description: Create groups of moving objects (using class and adding entities to the collection)
Add blocks created at point 1) to the collection
Subclass the BlockReference class for each moving group of objects
Override the BlockReference.Animate() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to compute the data for entities transformation at that specific time frame
Override the BlockReference.MoveTo() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to move the objects on the GPU

Override the BlockReference.IsInFrustum() method of the class at point 3) and return true without calling the base to avoid undesired clipping. It might be necessary to override also the bounding box scene extents
Add the block references created at point 3) to the collection
Call StartAnimation() providing the time interval between each frame
Call StopAnimation() to stop the animation

member.remarks: During animation the silhouettes, if enabled, are skipped.

Override the BlockReference.Animate() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to compute the data for entities transformation at that specific time frame
Override the BlockReference.MoveTo() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to move the objects on the GPU

Override the BlockReference.IsInFrustum() method of the class at point 3) and return true without calling the base to avoid undesired clipping. It might be necessary to override also the bounding box scene extents

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem.ParentName
member.summary: The block name of the first parent that contain that entity.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem.Parents
member.summary: The parents stack to reach the entity.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem.Entity
member.summary: The entity found intersecting in the resulting tuple.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType
member.summary: The accuracy type used during collision detection.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.OB
member.summary: Oriented Bounding check type- Computes a collision detection by using OrientedBoundingRect (for CollisionDetection2D) or OrientedBoundingBox (for CollisionDetection) intersection. The most approximated accuracy, the faster.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.SubdivisionTree
member.summary: Computes a collision detection by using intersection among QuadTree(for 2D) or Octree(for 3D) subdivision. More accurate than OB Accuracy, but slower during collision computation if the entities collection are transformed BlockReferences. Usefull for entities with complex but balanced tessellation.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.OBWithSubdivisionTree
member.summary: Computes a collision detection by using a combination of OBR/OBB and triangles/segments QuadTree/Octree subdivision intersections. Same accuracy of SubdivisionTree method, but faster during collision computation for deep Block\BlockReference gerarchy (it could be slower during computation of QuadTree\Octree and OBR\OBB data). Suggested for deep Block\BlockReferences hierarchy containing leaves entities with a complex/dense tessellation.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.Accurate
member.summary: Computes a collision detection by using Geometrical intersections. The most accurate but slower approach. Suggested if you need to find precise intersection for curved entities. Advised against animation and frequently translated entities.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionResult
member.summary: The resulting collision information after a Collision check between two colliding leaves entities.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionResult.CollidedEntities
member.summary: contains the information of both the colliding entities.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionResult.CollisionItems
member.summary: When is called, it is filled with the list of the intersection volumes found between the tuple . When false it is filled only during checkMethod with the collision information found during the ordinary check.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D._entities1
member.summary: Lists of entities to check during collision detection.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D._entities2
member.summary: Lists of entities to check during collision detection.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D._allToAll
member.summary: When true, it detects collition from a unique list of entities intersecting each others. When false, it takes two list of separate object. Detects wich entities of the first list intersect what of the second.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.Result
member.summary: The resulting collision Data subdivided for tuples of intersecting entities.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CheckMethod
member.summary: Gets or sets the collision accuracy type.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CoincidenceAsCollision
member.summary: When true it considers the coincidence between objects as collision. It avoids them otherwise.
member.remarks: The is not entirely supported yet. This could affect performances.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.FirstOnly
member.summary: When true the collision detection will stop at the first entities tuple found.

member.summary: Gets or sets the "Preparing data..." text string.

member.summary: Gets or sets the "Collision detection..." text string.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.ComputeIntersectionVolume
member.summary: Performs extra computation to find the intersection volumes of each Colliding Entities tuple. The is filled with the list of the intersection volumes found.
member.returns: The log of the single operation.
member.remarks: When the complex volumes computation fails, an easier accessible data is returned anyway if available.

member.summary: Computes the oriented bounding rect/box for all the entities in the groups (or update only the modified entities)

member.summary: Check collision among oriented bounding boxes of the entities groups
member.returns: True if at least two OBB intersects each other, false otherwise

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.TreesCollision(System.ComponentModel.BackgroundWorker,System.ComponentModel.DoWorkEventArgs)
member.summary: Check collision among octrees of the entities groups

member.returns: True if at least two OBB(or OBR) intersects each other, false otherwise

member.summary: Checks if two entity intersect geometrically.

the entity to check intersection with first

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Dicom.VolumeRendering
member.summary:
Utility class for the volume rendering reconstruction.
The volume rendering is a set of techniques used to display a 2D projection of a 3D discretely sampled data set, typically a 3D scalar field.
A typical 3D data set is a group of 2D slice images acquired by a CT, MRI, or MicroCT scanner. Usually these are acquired in a regular pattern (e.g., one slice every millimeter) and usually have a regular number of image pixels in a regular pattern. This is an example of a regular volumetric grid, with each volume element, or voxel represented by a single value that is obtained by sampling the immediate area surrounding the voxel.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Triangulation.ScalarField3D
member.summary: The function used by the marching cube algorithm to evaluate the 3D scalar field.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Triangulation.MarchingCubes
member.summary:
Utility class for creating a polygonal surface representation of an isosurface of a 3D scalar field.
There are many applications for this type of technique, two very common ones are:
Reconstruction of a surface from medical volumetric datasets. For example MRI scans result in a 3d volume of samples at the vertices of a regular 3D mesh.
Creating a 3D contour of a mathematical scalar field. In this case the function is known everywhere but is sampled at the vertices of a regular 3D grid.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Triangulation.MarchingCubes.LightWeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the triangulation output type.
member.remarks: If true, the coincident vertices of the generated mesh are not welded and the is set to , else the vertices are welded and the is set to The generated mesh is created with the same value.

member.summary: The function used by the marching squares algorithm to evaluate the 2D scalar field.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Triangulation.MarchingSquares
member.summary: Utility class for creating a polygonal representation of an isocurve of a 2D scalar field.

example.code:
Public Sub MarchingSquares() Dim func As ScalarField2D = New ScalarField2D(AddressOf myScalarField)
Dim ms As MarchingSquares = new MarchingSquares(new Point2D(0, 0), 100, 1, 100, 1, func) ms.IsoLevel = 20 ms.DoWork() Dim isoCurv As Line() = ms.Result Assert.AreEqual(156, isoCurv.Length) End Sub Private Function myScalarField(ByVal x1 As Single, ByVal y1 As Single) As Single Dim pt As Point2D = New Point2D(x1, y1) Dim cen As Point2D = New Point2D(50, 50) Return Convert.ToSingle(cen.DistanceTo(pt)) End Function

member.summary: Gets the estimated small size value in pixels.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Viewport.SmallSizeRatio

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid during dynamic movements (Zoom/Pan/Rotate). Default value is 0.01. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Viewport.SmallSizeRatioMoving

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid during dynamic movements (Zoom/Pan/Rotate). Default value is 0.01. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Viewport.SmallSizeRatioStill

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid on the still frames. Default value is 0. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.summary: Maps world coordinates to screen coordinates.

member.returns: The associated projected screen point (zero on bottom)
member.remarks: The z-component of the returned point is in the normalized device coordinate space [0,1]. A value outside the [0,1] range means that the point is outside the near-far clipping planes of the camera.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.RegenParams.Deviation
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum deviation. Determines the value between the analytical surface and its triangulation. The lower is the deviation value, the more accurate is the result.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.RegenParams.Angle
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum angular deflection in radians, ignored when zero.
member.remarks: This setting dictates the minimum number of facets around a smaller circle or cylinder regardless of the setting, and gives you added control over faces with very small radii. Lower values result in finer tessellations, while higher values give coarser tessellations.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.rotationCenterType.ViewportCenter
member.summary: Viewport center. If the model is all inside the camera frustum, it rotates around its bounding box center. Else it rotates around the viewport center at a mean depth of the current visible scene.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.rotationCenterType.CursorLocation
member.summary: Current mouse cursor location. If the model is all inside the camera frustum, it rotates around its bounding box center. Else it rotates around the point under the mouse. If under the mouse there is no depth, the rotation happens around the viewport center at a mean depth of the current visible scene.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.rotationCenterType.Point
member.summary: Rotates around the .

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.WorkUnit

summary.para: Base class for background working support. Overriding this class you can build a model or do your CPU intensive calculations on a separate thread keeping your application UI responsive.
Depending on the nature of the work you may need to override both the and methods or only the one and provide a to be notified when the work has completed.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Block
member.summary:
Block definition. Blocks have to be added to the master block array and inserted in the list using the entity.
A block in Eyeshot is a collection of entities that create an object, grouped together to make one selectable object. Selecting one particular entity will select all entities contained within the block. They can be moved, rotated, mirrored etc and will always be treated by Eyeshot as one whole object.
Blocks are an invaluable way of quickly arranging complex pieces of a model. Selecting the object is a breeze, it is no longer necessary to painstakingly select each individual entities. Blocks also make it easy to duplicate the same object throughout a drawing, and as Eyeshot recognizes that each copy of a block is identical to the previous, the memory and processing time required by Eyeshot is reduced.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Block.ConvexHull
member.summary: The convex hull of the surface.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Block.FullPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the forced full path for saving the file representing this block. Default value is null/Nothing.
member.remarks: This property is used when saving a file in a format supporting MultiFile feature, to force the destination output path for the single block (assembly or sub-assembly). By design, all files of the same assembly are stored in the same directory, but you can force a different path for a single assembly by using this property. It must include absolute path, filename and extension. When saving an assembly in Eyeshot MultiFile format, each block is automatically saved in the same directory specified for . If the block is not the root one, the name for the exported file is get from the block's itself. and the extension will be get according to the property. If the property is filled, it overrides the above automatism of course.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Block.CustomData
member.summary: Gets or sets a custom object that will be stored to the Eyeshot Proprietary File Format.

remarks.para: You need to define the related for your custom data and you need to use a custom including definition for it.
If the type implements ICloneable it will be cloned when the Block is cloned.

member.seealso: The article about Eyeshot Proprietary File Format.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.GetOffsetForSelection
member.summary: Gets the offset applied to the camera planes for the drawing of the selected entities.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.GetProjectionMatrix(System.Double,System.Double,devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.CameraEyePosType)
member.summary: Gets the projection matrix.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.SetupModelView(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,devDept.Eyeshot.Environment.CameraEyePosType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gives a chance to derived classes to setup camera by two points and a vector.

example.code:
Public Class myCamera Inherits devDept.Eyeshot.Camera
Private myLocation As New Point3D(100, 0, 0) Private myTarget As Point3D = Point3D.Origin Private myUpVector As Vector3D = Vector3D.AxisZ
Protected Overrides Sub SetupModelView(setGraphics As Boolean, reflection As Boolean, cameraEyePos As Environment.CameraEyePosType) modelViewMatrix = LookAt(myLocation, myTarget, myUpVector, reflection)
If setGraphics AndAlso renderContext IsNot Nothing Then renderContext.SetMatrices(projectionMatrix, modelViewMatrix) End If End Sub
End Class
Public Class Form1
Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load
MyViewport.Camera = New MyCamera
End Sub
End Class

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.NearPlaneDistanceFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the factor used to compute the near plane from the far plane distance.
member.remarks: By default it is 0.001 of the far plane distance. Set it to a smaller value if it's clipping too much geometry near the viewer in big scenes. Beware that too small values affect the scene rendering precision.
Call the and to see the effect of the change.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.WorldToScreen(devDept.Geometry.Point3D,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Maps world coordinates to screen mouse coordinates.
member.param: The 3D point to project on screen
member.returns: The associated projected screen point relative to the viewport (zero on bottom)
member.remarks: The z-component of the returned point is in the normalized device coordinate space [0,1]. A value outside the [0,1] range means that the point is outside the near-far clipping planes of the camera.

member.remarks: The z-component of the returned point is in the normalized device coordinate space [0,1]. A value outside the [0,1] range means that the point is outside the near-far clipping planes of the camera.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.UtilityEx.CheckDataIntegrity(System.String@,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{System.String}}}@)
member.summary:
Checks the data integrity between the Environment controls.
It compares item-by-item all the master collections of all the Environment instances, searching for objects used in more than one Environment.
member.param: The log file containing details about shared items.

The dictionary containing the shared items.
Listed below are the element types you can find in it
- Layer: items that belong to the collection.
- Block: items that belong to the collection.
- Material: items that belong to the collection.
- TextStyle: items that belong to the collection.
- LineType: items that belong to the collection.
- HatchPattern: items that belong to the collection.
- Entity: items that belong to the collection.
- BlockEntity: items that belong to the collection.
- BlockEntity+Entity: items that belong both to the and to the collections.
member.returns: True when no instances are shared between different Environment controls, otherwise false.
member.remarks: You can't share objects (i.e. , , , etc.) between different Environment controls, but you need to clone them before adding to another Environment control. If you get wrong display results or artifacts, you can use this method to check out shared elements.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.UtilityEx.GetLinesTangentToTwoCircles(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle)
member.summary: Computes the segments tangent to two given circles or arcs.
member.returns: The array of lines tangent to both circles. For arcs, it returns only the lines that touch them.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.UtilityEx.GetLinesTangentToTwoCircles(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Line[]@)
member.summary: Computes the segments tangent to two given circles.
member.param: Array of length 4 containing the tangent lines.
member.returns: The number of not null lines in .
member.remarks:
For arcs, it returns the same result as for circles, for a different result use . All the lines start from c1 and end on c2, except for the tangent lines that are perpendicular to the line connecting the two centers, we will refer to these tangents as vertical or VERT: their length is equal to the diameter of the bigger circle and they touch the circles at the midPoint. The position of the lines in the array is fixed and dependent from the number of solutions:
[0] upper external (or outer),
[1] lower external (or outer),
[2] upper internal (or inner),
[3] lower internal (or inner). To define upper we use the positive direction of the Y axis of the plane with axis Z equal to c1.Plane, and axis X given by the direction c1.Center-c2.Center. Based on the number of solutions, the possibilities are:
0 => [null, null, null, null]: one circle is completely inside the other and they don't intersect,
1 => [null, null, null, VERT]: one circle is completely inside the other and they are tangent
2 => [LINE, LINE, null, null]: the circles intersect in two different points, there are only the external tangents,
3 => [LINE, LINE, VERT, null]: the circles intersect in one point, but they aren't one inside the other, there are the external tangents and a vertical tangent,
4 => [LINE, LINE, LINE, LINE]: the circles don't intersect and they aren't one inside the other, there are the external tangents and the internal tangents.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.UtilityEx.GetCirclesTangentToTwoCircles(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Computes the circles tangent to two given circles or arcs.
member.param: The radius of the tangent circles
If true, it trims the tangent circle at the tangent points.
It is significant only when trim is true. If false (default) it returns the shortest part of the tangent circle, if true it returns the longest part.
member.returns: The array of circles tangent to both circles. For arcs, it returns only the circles that touch them. The StartPoint of the output circles lie always on c1. If trim is true, the trimmed arc goes from c1 to c2.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.UtilityEx.GetLinesTangentToCircleFromPoint(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Geometry.Point3D,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Line[]@)
member.summary: Computes the tangent lines from a point to a circle.
member.param: The point on the circle's plane and outside it.
Array containing the not-null tangent lines.
member.remarks: For arcs, it returns only the lines that touch them. The tangent lines are directed from the point toward the circle.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.UtilityEx.GetLinesTangentToCircleFromPoint(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Geometry.Point3D)
member.summary: Computes the tangent lines from a point to a circle.
member.param: The point on the circle's plane and outside it.
member.returns: Returns a Line-type array of length 2 containing the tangent lines from the point to the circle. A Null array if the point is inside the circle or if the point does not lie on the circle's plane.
member.remarks: For arcs, it returns even the tangent line that do not touch the arc. For a different result use . The tangent lines are directed from the point toward the circle.

True when an object has been read, otherwise false.

member.returns: The updated instance; this may be different to the instance argument if either the original instance was null, or the stream defines a known sub-type of the original instance.
